column3: All of the above, especially the PI, but also researchers who attempt to reproduce. They must adapt models, methods and other elements for research to be reproducible in diverse contexts. This is paradoxical but mostly true.
column7: every researchers should have this goal in mind as an ethical requirement, and it should be a requirement  at least where there is public funding (which is the case in a lot of private corporations in many countrires)
column13: Question assumes that reproducibility should be enforced - don't agree
column14: Researcher's institution should provide more incentives to consider reproducibility
column15: Researchers (scientist, students, post doc, Principle investigator, etc)  who are producing the data should be ethical enough to produce  reproducible data
column19: Whoever wants to test a given case. Reproducibility is the definitive testament of knowledge production, so aligning it as a condition of publication/funding is absurd and requires a specific epistemological orientation that delimits Geography as a discipline. Let's not refight the quantitative revolution, eh?
